Triphosphite hydrolizes, big deal  As free neuclutide loses its triphosphate In the growing strand, there goes my chain! Life not that stupid Why life evolved that way Triphosphate must be floating freely always Where primer come from An enzyme specially made for primers Primase 11:14 Primer gaps by Okazaki (fragments) Issue they're not connected! Polymarease copies dna , bumps into next primer, which got to be connected ligate( ligature) Enzyme ligase Primase makes Rna [easier from scratch] then get extended to Dna & sips as ce the Rna Topological problem I don't know how cell Make a primer Trying to copy 2 dna strands they're wrapped around other Tug them apart to make new strand I have to send copies to 2 daughter cells! Imagine a circle wrapped with gazillion wraps Possible no topological deformation Moebius strand 2 circles clwrapped around cannot be separated Every cell cuts it Branches are topoisomers have same chem formula Different topology not wrapped around 20:40 why right base go in? Hydrogen bonding At GC, so wrong base can never go in How much more unfavored (probability) Because it's less good -energetically How much =delta G (wrong base) Equilibrium constant for wrong base Keq=10^3 for right base(10^-3 for wrong base) Quality control: For protein coding  Typical gene is 2000 based of proteins coding Guarantees 2 mistakes per cell division Polymarease 5 to 3  exonuclease 3 to 5 Adds base in one dire Goes back takes bases out Ita proofreading its worbenefit k equilibrium of original base Separate equilibrium for proofreading Down to 10^-5 10^-6 1 error per million cell division Fidelity  Replication 10^-3 Proofreading 10^-6 If you put in wrong base  Width helix not right Sbape is wrong Mismatch repair system If error let's helix bludge, the repair cuts removes dna 10^-8 10^-9 Genome is 3 10^-9, now 1 2 errors per genome If cell has no cope for sna replication the. You're high risk of cancer (colon) Heredity polyps coli You lose the repair mismatch thus lose the other good copy, by chance then that cell can cause cancer Speed  Polymerase able to polarize 2000 nucleotides per second Installs right base accuracy 99.9 Proof reads as it goes Kornberg just found minor polymerase, does tidying & clean up actual main enzyme is a more complicated one Chemistry genetically only from biochemical,  genetic pov only know that from genetics (purified by biochemistry) Most cells have multi polymerases How does polymerase know which 1 is right, as 50% you're wrong -What bacteria do? Mark their dna with methyl groups Some enzyme at a certain position, Mark's it with a methyl group Now have meth marked 2 helix Upon replication, the new copy strand, lacks the methyl group Bow you can distinguish between new & old itll get them eventually, but mismatch repair is faster It only looks for methylgroups, like bread crumbs, it inspects (this is old, that's new strand)

In case you didn't know, this guy was a mathematician before becoming a geneticist and, notably, was a medalist in international mathematical olympiad as a kid. I don't know if this is something he carries from his maths background, or if this course is structured this way because it's not strictly intended for biology majors, but he teaches biology in a very, kind of, logical way, which makes this stuff all the more interesting and memorable.

I have a good question here: If transcription occurs on just one of the strands, then why is it that heterozygous genes will only ever express the dominant gene? Let's say the template strand has the gene for blond hair, and the non-template strand has the gene for black hair. Surely then, only the blond hair gene is transcribed and translated? The individual would have blond hair. But we also know that the black hair gene dominates the blond hair gene. So what's going on?

@earthworm-filledstomachbyc4254  every fossil found supports evolution.  The earliest life on earth was the most simple, the oldest fossil containing rocks on earth only contain simple life. A nucleoside triphosphate + H2O   \rightleftharpoons  a nucleotide + diphosphate Thus, the two substrates of this enzyme are nucleoside triphosphate and H2O, whereas its two products are nucleotide and diphosphate.  This enzyme belongs to the family of hydrolases, specifically those acting on acid anhydrides in phosphorus-containing anhydrides. The systematic name of this enzyme class is nucleoside-triphosphate diphosphohydrolase. This enzyme is also called nucleoside-triphosphate pyrophosphatase. This enzyme participates in purine metabolism and pyrimidine metabolism.  For example, enzyme deoxyribonucleoside triphosphate pyrophosphatase, encoded by YJR069C in S. cerevisiae and exhibiting (d)ITPase and (d)XTPase activities, hydrolyses ITP, dITP, XTP and dXTP releasing pyrophosphate and IMP, dIMP, XMP and dXMP, respectively....... or something like that 😁😁😁

Can anyone describe me regarding why the question arises at 7minutes of the video?

you are not paying attention to the fact that bacteria replicate about once every twenty minutes. Think how many bacteria there are and how many billions of years they've been replicating every twenty minutes (doubling the population each time). Then throw in the random chance of a beneficial mutation and how that offspring wins in the competition for space and food. etc. This is not as miraculous as it appears to us... although the whole scheme of chemistry and the right conditions in a universe of big burning spheres is a very big idea for us to comprehend.

3:00 the lecturer says “a phosphate” but writes Ag

Because if go from 3' to 5' that means the nucleotides should bind on phosphate group. The phosphate group keeps the reaction going. But if the three phosphate groups are sticking which is quite unstable it makes it difficult for nucleotides to bind because three phosphates are in the way and the three phosphates is quite instable and if it hydrolysis without binding you will have a big problem. The replication process comes to a halt.
Watch this video and ask your question in the comment section of the video  https://youtu.be/egpB9anFsvo
Good luck!

The polymerase responsible for the mismatch repair system is a different form of polymerase than the polymerase that does most replication.   In eukaryotes, polymerase delta replicates lagging strands and polymerase epsilon replicates the leading strand. The mismatch repair system is polymerase beta, which has a much lower fidelity. Hope this helps.

Damn.  I just caught an error.   at 22 minutes in he talks about errors in replication.   He says one error per 1000 bases, and a gene is 2000 bases, so 2 error per CELL DIVISION.  What he means is 2 errors PER GENE per cell division.  With 20,000 genes if we count that way, thats 40,000 errors in active genes per cell division, but with 3 billion bases, it's actually about 3 million errors per cell division.       I have watched a large number of his lectures, and this is the first technical error I have seen him make, (the only other gripe I have was not giving Rosalind Franklin her real due in the process of discovering DNA), so I'm TOTALLY willing to cut him some slack here.  I have to say, overall, he is the secondbest lecturer/teacher I have EVER seen, and the top of my list is my 8th grade math teacher who impacted my life personally, so clearly, you can take that with a grain of salt.

He mentions that Primase puts RNA on in an aside, but then says that for all purposes that it may as well be DNA instead. Cells have another enzyme that comes in and swaps the RNA primer out for DNA as well though! It is called DNA Polymerase I. Just guessing that for sake of simplicity, he left that out.
The enzyme that takes it out is rnase and then ligase comes in and seals the "nick" left by the removal. DNA polymerase comes in and acts as an exonuclease 5'-->3' and adds DNA to Okazaki fragment.

It is because addition of each new nucleotide on the growing chain requires a free 3' hydroxyl group to which the incoming nucleotides 5' phosphate would react. This would lead to the formation of new bond with the release of pyrophosphate. However, when you proceed from 3' to 5' no such free 3' hydroxyl group is available and hence reaction can't proceed in that direction. I hope this makes it clear. [Check the chemical structure of the nucleotides, you will understand what I mean.]

It unwinds as helicases travel along DNA, opening it up at an intersection called the replication fork. Around that area the newly synthesized strands surely won't get entangled, but as the fork moves further away I assume that chemical forces take over and end up entangling the strands. For my second question, I believe I figured it out.    If you had pppApppTpppCpppCpppC, and those phosphates hydrolyzed, the rest of the growing DNA chain would be destroyed.  That makes sense.  However, why not allow the phosphates to be hydrolyzed prior being attached at the 3' end?

I cannot understand why DNA Ploymerase 1.)  Needs an RNA Primer  2.)  can only add nucleotides to the 3' end.  The professor addresses my second question around 7:50, but I couldn't conceptualize what he is saying "It is bad to invest your tri-phospates into the growing strand because if they hydrolyze you loose your growing strand?"  By what mechanism?  Are the tri-phosphate nucleotides hydrolyzing randomly in the nucleus?  If they are, how is the energy harvested?  Why is that optimal?
